title: Tamzin Outhwaite webchat â as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: 'when i was in red cap i did get lots of mail from people saying : `` you 're the reason i joined the army '' '
'for my eastenders audition , there were 20 boys and 20 girls . i distinctly remember wearing pedal pushers '
'people come up with storylines for me : `` i 'm sure you owe phil 30 grand for bail '' ! '
'in 20 years ' time , i 'd like to be still friends with my children '
top 5 table sauces : 'stokes garlic mayonnaise . heinz tomato ketchup . hp sauce . chicken shop smoky barbecue sauce . soy '
'what i love about theatre is that you never have to watch it back '

documents.title: that 's all for today ¦
text: guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 2:01pm well , that was fun .
thank you all so much for your questions .
if you like to laugh , come to see how the other half loves at the theatre royal , haymarket - we 're on until june 25 .
the episode of inside no 9 , series three , will be on this autumn on bbc2 .

documents.title: 'when i was in red cap i did get lots of mail from people saying : `` you 're the reason i joined the army '' '
text: antiquarian asks : there used to be a publicity shot of you in red cap on the media appearances board in hq training estates south east , where you filmed .
they said it was the most stolen image , more so than 007 .
any other unusual accolades like that ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 2:00pm i used to be seeded number three in trampolining in redbridge .
and in all-girls doubles , tennis , me and my partner were seeded number two .
only for a year , mind , but it 's still quite an accolade .
i was told by the army advisors that we used on red cap that over the two year period it was shown , figures of women joining shot up .
when it was on , i used to get lots of fan mail , people saying : you 're the reason i joined the army .
id5279263 asks : do you expect the work to dry up as you get older ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:57pm surely everything dries up as you get older .
tamzin as rebecca in hotel babylon .

/colin bell mortonsfork asks : i loved hotel babylon and thought you were absolutely brilliant in it has finding out all the secrets that go on behind the scenes at hotels changed the way you feel about them in real life are you more keen to stay in them , or less ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:57pm from working on hotel babylon i learned little things , like asking for an extra pillow means asking for a prostitute .
so i made sure never to ask for one .
darkus asks : i appreciate it may change from day to day ( i know mine does ) , but i wondered what your top five records ( songs or albums ) of all time are on this beautiful sunny day ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:54pm red flag by all saints right now .
marvin gaye 's what 's going on .
carole king 's tapestry .
elbow , the seldom seen kid .
joni mitchell 's blue .

documents.title: 'for my eastenders audition , there were 20 boys and 20 girls . i distinctly remember wearing pedal pushers '
text: harpervalleypta asks : you have performed a lot of challenging roles .
how did you get your eastenders role ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:53pm i went to a workshop at elstree , which julia crampsie had invited me to , and there were 20 boys and 20 girls .
i distinctly remember wearing pedal pushers .
the boys were up for the character that jack ryder got , and the girls were up for mel .
i remember very clearly that i was a little late , and i have a phobia of being late .
i rushed in , and thought , oh i 've messed this up .
we did a workshop for what felt like six hours , and a couple of days later i was at tottenham court road station from an audition for something .
it was in the days of the pager , and there were lots of payphones - my pager said `` call your agent '' .
the producer matthew wanted to speak to me , he gave me the number to call .
i got enough change in case it was a long call .
i remember shaking , phoning him .
it was a conference call , with julie and matthew , and he said where are you ?
are you prepared for your life to change ?
that 's what i remember .
it was just a three month contract though ; if they renewed it , great .
and three months turned into three and a half years .
instead of getting a bus , i hailed a taxi - that was a sign of victory , as i could now afford it .
i went straight round to my friend 's house in islington , and said : you 're not going to believe it !
hailsuk asks : would you rather be in the same play for a year or do a different play every month ?

guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:48pm the idea of doing a different character every month is great - like in the old-school rep companies , where you 'd cross over in different productions all the time : a musical , a comedy it does n't happen really any more .
i worked at the stephen joseph theatre with alan ayckbourn , but that was luck with him recasting me , not being part of a rep company .
those companies kept you on your toes .
all saints in concert , april 2016 .
isaac/rex shutterstock manwithoutfriends asks : you recently attended the all saints comeback gig at koko and are good friends with the band .
what 's your favourite song from the new album ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:47pm i am good friends with the band .
i met nicole in 1998 , we 've been friends ever since .
i love their new album , i think it 's probably up there with my favourites of theirs , and my favourite song is who hurt who , one strike , and pieces .
i was a massive fan before i met them , we all walked around in maharishi pants and tried to dress like them .
and then , i think shaznay is an amazing writer , and all of them - they all write and sing brilliantly and they look amazing , what 's not to like ?
their songs are all really catchy - some are really down and dirty with heavy bass , and some are really good pop songs .
denloved asks : i thought that when you began in eastenders you were a breath of fresh air to the cast .
i also saw you in a bbc drama .
you played a single mother of a young boy who was being bullied .
i read in a magazine years ago under their headline of famous people they had snapped on camera , one of those shots were of you and mos def having lunch .
is this true ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:44pm no comment
ray roscoe asks : ever considered going in to the ice-cream business if the acting dries up ?
after all , it 's in the blood , right ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:43pm as far as i know , most italians were in the ice-cream business .
my friend annalisa rossi is from the rossi ice-cream family ; daniela nardini , i think they were an ice-cream family .
peter capaldi , he 's from an ice-cream family - although i might be wrong there .
they all seem to be in catering and mainly ice-cream .
there 's always been a side of me that likes to cook and serve food - maybe i 'll open up my own cafe with an ice-cream section .
25aubrey asks : what and who gives you the biggest belly laughs ?
i just watched young frankenstein on dvd and it 's still hilarious after all these years.what movie tickles your funny bones ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:41pm there are certain characters that will always tickle me .
john cleese in fawlty towers , alan partridge in absolutely everything .
they 're just iconic characters .
david brent might be in there for me .
i could watch the trip and the thick of it on a loop .
more mainstream , i love modern family , i think phil is a classic character .
it 's the most complete sitcom we have in 30 minutes , so it 's rounded off and is feelgood .
i love reece shearsmith and steve pemberton , the majority of stuff they do - inside no 9 , i 've done an episode of it , and it was very hard to get through without laughing .
they 're so clever .

documents.title: 'people come up with storylines for me : `` i 'm sure you owe phil 30 grand for bail '' ! '
text: tamzin outhwaite in red cap .
keyte/bbc paddy01 asks : i always enjoyed redcap and would have liked another series .
perhaps you could make a guest appearance in the next series of our girl ? i thought new tricks could have continued though .
i did n't think a major cast change would work , but the new team realy gelled and i was realy enjoying the series again .
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:38pm i loved making red cap .
i did weapon training with the army and slept on a very crispy mattress for a week .
so i often feel like my fighting , weapon , and army skills could be used in another program i hate to think it 's all gone to waste .
i would love to see red cap on dvd , i have so many people asking about it , but it has n't happened yet .
we all feel like we could have continued new tricks , but there 's a lovely element to it that we leave people wanting more .
which is very similar to red cap , i just did two series of that of two series of new tricks .
i often think a new tricks christmas special would be a good idea .
i do daydream of dormant storylines what storyline could i go back to eastenders on when there 's no family members there ?
people come up with storylines for me - `` go back with your teenage son to find ian beale '' , `` i 'm sure you own 30 grand to phil for bail ! ''
sackdacrenow asks : is it true that woody allen gives actors very little direction ?
and if so , is n't that disappointing for actors who get the chance to work with him ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:33pm i only worked for a few days with woody allen , and i was very much in awe of him .
he would watch what we did , and then talk about the scene afterwards .
there definitely was n't an abundance of direction - but i loved his passion for food which he talked about quite a lot .
iain sharp asks : are you still scuba diving and where 's your best war /cold water dive sites ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:31pm i have n't scuba dived since my children were born , seven years ago .
i specifically learned for the dolphin show with the bbc , but after i learned i chose my holiday destinations based on scuba diving - until my children came along and holidays changed for good .

i 'm keen to revist them asap , although i might need a refresher course my favourite sites were the indian ocean - anywhere around the maldives , mauritius and seychelles , all have the most vibrant underwater life .
the biggest disappointment was the great barrier reef , where it seemed a lot of the coral has died , and visibility was poor .
i had been spoiled in the indian ocean by then , though .
but i do think it 's one of the most peaceful places to be - it 's making me want to go now !
modhabobo asks : how often is the phrase oh tamzin , i loved the song sleeping satellite !
said to you , and how do you tell them that you 're not tasmin archer ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:29pm when the song was out , i definitely heard that phrase , but that was many moons ago .
although now i have to remind people that i 'm tamzin , not tazmin , and sometimes they shorten it to tas .
i have to politely say : it 's a z , not an s .
shakercoola asks : the bbc 's who do you think you are ?
programme revealed your italian heritage but your surname is prevalent in west yorkshire .
do you have northern roots ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:28pm my dad 's surname is outhwaite , and a thwaite is a woodland clearing - and that 's a yorkshire name .
but outhwaite is very rare .
my parents were both born in the east end of london , but my dad has northern roots .

documents.title: 'in 20 years ' time , i 'd like to be still friends with my children '
text: fatharrywhite asks : what do you want to be doing in 20 years ' time ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:27pm travelling .
still working .
still friends with my children .
playing the piano and the guitar .
speaking fluent italian .
and laughing lots .

documents.title: top 5 table sauces : 'stokes garlic mayonnaise . heinz tomato ketchup . hp sauce . chicken shop smoky barbecue sauce . soy '
text: hp vammyp asks : i 've got two questions i 've been dying to ask you:1 .
have you ever met les dennis ? 2 .
what are your top 5 table sauces ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:26pm 1 .
i met les dennis when he came in to play a guest role on hotel babylon .
he was charming and a lovely actor .
stokes garlic mayonnaise .
heinz tomato ketchup .
hp sauce .
chicken shop smoky barbecue sauce .
soy .
queequeg7 asks : why did you marry ian beale ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:24pm mel married ian beale because they got on well .
ian had taken her under his wing and given her a job ; she loved his kids .
and i think she fell for him .
the reason that she left him four hours after marrying was that she found out he lied about his daughter having cancer .
this was the millenium eve episode , and 20 million people watched it .
i went trekking to madagascar - i wanted to get away from it all .
it was quite nice being on the opposite side of the earth with no television .
but i was told they played it on big screens on trafalgar square - apparently you could hear a pin drop when i said `` i do '' .
the scale of it was ridiculous .
it was a wonderful thing to feel part of , but remembering it was n't real was imperative at the time

documents.title: 'what i love about theatre is that you never have to watch it back '
text: gina mckee ( viv ) , tamzin outhwaite ( di ) and anna maxwell martin ( rose ) in di and viv and rose by amelia bullmore .
kenton for the guardian hailsuk asks : i loved di , viv and rose , and you are fantastic in the comedy role of teresa # htohl .
do you ever get nervous before a show ?
how do you handle it ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:20pm yes i always get nervous , especially when the show has only just started .
and press night is always nervewracking .

it becomes less nervewracking as the run goes on , but if i did any one show without nerves i would have to give up - the nerves breed the adrenaline and allow you to go on in whatever state of tiredness you 're in .
part of the attraction is the addiction to adrenaline - if you can turn the nerves into adrenaline , and not fear , you 're ok .
fear will stop you doing things - experimenting and playing on stage .
adrenaline will give you the freedom to do things , and keep learning .
as i found last night - two props in a row betrayed me .
and it keeps you on your toes , you have to listen , improvise , stay in the moment and the character .
the adrenaline notches up tenfold , and that 's what keeps it interesting .
if it was exactly the same every night , it would n't be theatre .
and also , what i love about theatre , is that you never have to watch it back .
you never analyse your performance - how you see yourself is never going to be accurate .
but as long as your performance is never locked down in theatre , then it feels like there 's less ego involved .
you never have to watch it .
and that 's one of the reasons why i love theatre - you 're inside your journey , you never see it from outside .
tv and film is a different adrenaline .
tamzin and a dolphin chatterjee/bbc teazub asks : i remember being transfixed by your documentary on swimming with dolphins .
it 's always struck me as a shame you have n't done more documentary work , as you were very engaging as a host .
is that something which appeals in the future , and what to would you be most interested in covering ?

guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:15pm i absolutely loved doing tamzin outhwaite swimming with dolphins - but to do a show like that , it has to be a subject matter you 're extremely passionate about .

kate thornton and i made a holiday programme for the bbc many years ago where we went to sydney and tasmania , and who do you think you are was probably the closest i 've done to a documentary since .
if i was offered something i was passionate about i would definitely do it .
i 'm passionate about dance , theatre , travel , sport , interior design - there 's many things .
music , art , urban art

documents.title: 'i would come back as a gibson 335 , ideally an early-1960s example '
text: mickyfong asks : dear tamzin fender strat or gibson les paul which guitar would you reincarnate as ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:12pm ideally , i would not come back as either .
i would come back as a gibson 335 , ideally an early-1960s example .
phillondon123 asks : really enjoyed your performance in how the other half loves .
as a modern , 21st century woman , how do you feel about the about how the female characters in the play , which is set in the 1970s , are portrayed ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:11pm alan ayckbourn writes incredibly well for women .
even the women in this play , which was written in 1969 , one of them who is being bullied gets her comeuppance and status-wise becomes more powerful .
my character , terry , and her husband bob are either shagging or shouting and the power shifts between those two , so you never feel like the women are downtrodden .
and if they do have a sense of being bullied , they become triumphant in the end .
alan 's also not afraid to write sometimes unlikeable male characters .
i 'm not sure if it 's how , in 2016 , i or many of my friends would deal with relationships - that 's a sign of 1969 .
people did n't get divorced easily - they stuck together , and worked through it .
so when you have a play like this about marital manners , there are going to be many more ups and downs , because the marriages last for longer .
eddiebeagle asks : do you still consider out of control your best work ?
i can remember what a profoundly moving film it was and what a stunning review your performance was given in the times the next day .
ca n't recall one like it guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:08pm it stays with me as the single most effective piece of work i 've been involved in .
it was completely improvised so each day we never knew what was going to come out of our mouths - we were just given a synopsis of a scene , and we improvised .
it was terrifying and harrowing to be part of , but i 'm very proud of it .

the subject matter was that i was a mum of a teenage boy who 'd got into the wrong gang and ended up being sent to a young offender 's institute , and the events after that , that were completely out of my character 's control , could happen to anybody .
at the time , it was the most current and truthful piece of work i 've been a part of .
and to be part of something where everybody in it is firing on all cylinders and improvising , the result was quite outstanding .
it won best film at edinburgh film festival ; it won many awards , and i think i was the first person on bbc1 to say the c-word although i 'm sure when they showed it again , they had to beep it .
and also , working with dominic savage was inspiring , and i 'd love to work with him again .
it 's the thing that people often come up to me in the street and say : i remember you in that .
it sticks with people .
anyone listening ?
roberto martinez pond/getty images rosscandyfloss asks : should roberto martinez persist with the tactic of playing it out from the back ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:04pm i would say as long as john stones is playing at centre-back , yes .
but i 'll discuss this with bill kenwright .

documents.title: i 'm more of a hip-hop chick . i 'm old-school public enemy , slum village , krs-one ¦ '
text: asparagusnextleft asks : what 's your favourite lemmy track ?
guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:04pm it 's a toss-up between ace of spades , killed by death and ace of spades that 's a joke .
i 'm much more of a hip-hop chick .
i 'm old-school - kind of public enemy , slum village , krs-one
rubia84 asks : tamzin , i am playing di in one of the first amateur runs of di and viv and rose in the south of england .
the play is full of challenges for di , and i am mindful of portraying her faithfully without resorting to stereotypes .
any advice ?

guardian contributor tamzinouthwaite 13 april 2016 1:02pm my advice would be that di is the lynchpin , the pragmatic centre of the home that they live in , and it would be easy to play for laughs - but because she 's straight down the line and tells the truth about everything , it 's got to be played with truth , as she 's so rooted in her beliefs .
she knows who she is at such a young age , which is very rare .
and mainly : enjoy it .
di enjoys life ; you have to enjoy the play .
tamzin outhwaite is at guardian towers now tamzin outhwaite in the guardian offices for a webchat beaumont-thomas for the guardian

documents.title: post your questions for tamzin outhwaite
text: for many people , tamzin outhwaite will eternally be melanie owen , one of the most memorable of eastenders ' flawed heroines more than 20 million people tuned in to see her marry ian beale on the eve of the millennium , and her subsequent tempestuous relationships with steve owen and phil mitchell cemented her soap legend status .

but she has also appeared in a huge variety of other work , from woody allen film cassandra 's dream to tv hits like new tricks , and a host of stage productions including the acclaimed west end runs of sweet charity and di and viv and rose .

she 's currently starring in alan ayckbourn 's adultery farce how the other half loves , described by the guardian 's michael billington as a cleverly orchestrated revival that reminds us just what a comic master ayckbourn is .
tamzin will join us to answer your questions about anything in her career , in a live webchat from 1pm bst on wednesday 13 april .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The former EastEnders star is back in the West End, and she came in to talk about reincarnating as a guitar, HP sauce, training with the army and lots more.
